metadata.title: Epicondylitis, Medial
anatomical location body part affected: Medial epicondyle of the humerus, at the common attachment site of the wrist flexor and pronator tendons (flexor carpi radialis, pronator teres, flexor carpi ulnaris, palmaris longus, and ulnar collateral ligament)
description: Tendinosis of the wrist flexors and pronator tendons (i.e., pronator teres and common extensor tendon of flexor digitorum superficialis, flexor carpi ulnaris, flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus) at the medial epicondyle of the humerus. The terms epicondylosis or epicondylalgia more accurately describe the condition than epicondylitis(15)

Overuse tendon injury should be considered tendinopathy, not inflammatory tendonitis(15) –Underlying pathology is degeneration and formation of granulation tissue (also known as angiofibroblastic hyperplasia or tendinosis –The presence of an inflammatory component early in the disease process has not been ruled out –One hypothesis is that there are four stages in the progression of epicondylar tendinosis, all related to repetitive micro-tearing  of the tendon with inadequate reparation:(15) -Generalized inflammation -Angiofibroblastic degeneration -Structural failure -Fibrosis and calcification
Chronic medial epicondylitis usually involves some flexor-pronator  tendon degeneration; i.e., tendinopathy without inflammation(1)
Medial epicondylalgia (ME) is not as common as lateral epicondylalgia(2)
Affects women more than men, often in the 4th–6th decades of life(2)

ICD-10 codes.M77.0: medial epicondylitis (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Pain and tenderness with palpation at medial epicondyle(1)
Increased medial elbow pain with resisted wrist flexion and pronation(1,2)
Medial-sided  elbow pain that is exacerbated by daily activities may radiate to forearm(1,15)
Loss of full elbow extension may develop(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Acute injury–Typically secondary to a collision
Chronic injury–Frequently results from overuse; i.e., repetitive forceful wrist flexion and forearm pronation activities that producerebound wrist extension and forearm supination(1,2,15)
pathogenesis: Inflammation of the medial epicondyle and surrounding structures may be present in the early stage, but is less likely inchronic presentation;(15) see Description , above
Repetitive overuse creates stress on the tendon (often valgus stress at the elbow), resulting in microtears to the tendonorigin(15)
Angiofibroblastic hyperplasia characteristic of tendinosis is commonly present(15)
risk factors: Baseball pitching in children and adolescents, golfing, and other provocative activities(16)

overall contraindications precautions: Respect patient’s pain while performing the examination, especially during special tests, manual muscle tests, and neural tension tests
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When did symptoms begin? With what activities is the patient having difficulties? What has been the progression of symptoms?

course of treatment.medical management: Nonsurgical supportive care for ME includes modified rest (activity modification), painrelieving  modalities (e.g., medications, physical agent modalities, corticosteroid injections), structured rehabilitation, counterforce bracing, wrist orthosis, or kinesiology taping. Surgical management typically is reserved for patients with intractable symptoms
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? NSAIDs administered topically or orally can help to reduce inflammation and pain in early stage of ME(2,15) Use of NSAIDs is questionable in chronic cases of ME because inflammation may not be a component of the pathology(1)
diagnostic tests completed: X-ray  may be used to assist in differential diagnosis of ME, ruling out osteoarthritis, osteochondrosis dissecans, or other bony abnormalities.(2)MRI is the gold standard and may be used to confirm diagnosis and determine severity. In  some cases, ultrasound may be a reasonable alternative to MRI. EMG may be required to determine if there is ulnar nerve involvement(15)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Symptoms are brought on by precipitating repetitious activity (e.g., early return to golf)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Patients usually report pain and tenderness with palpation at medial epicondyle that may radiate to forearm or wrist(15)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Is pain localized or generalized? Does pain radiate?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., paresthesias) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What recreational or competitive sports does the patient participate in? Child and adolescent baseball pitchers, golfers, and others participating in a provocative activity (work, repetitive activities) are at risk for medial epicondylitis(15,16)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Assess for provocative activities; assess ability to perform work duties and participate in leisure activities and sports

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Complete a general exam as indicated with a focus on the items listed below •Anthropometric measurements : Circumference at elbow for swelling •Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Assess for involvement of the ulnar nerve with neural tension test(5) -Evaluate with the greatest tension on the nerve obtained through -shoulder depression -external rotation and abduction of the extremity -flexion at the elbow -supination at the forearm -extension at the wrist -neck lateral flexion to the opposite side -Assess median and radial nerve tension as indicated  –Ergonomics/body mechanics : Assess repetitive movement technique (e.g., in sports) associated with pain for improper form that may contribute to underlying pathology –Joint integrity and mobility : Assess for lateral and medial instability of the elbow (ulnar collateral ligament instability). Also assess radial/ulnar mobility
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: –Muscle strength -Grip strength commonly is decreased due to pain.(3,5)Assess with hand dynamometer -See Special tests specific to diagnosis , below -A cervical screen should be completed to assist in ruling out neck pathology as the underlying source of pain; muscle test neck flexion, extension, lateral flexion, and rotation(6)
observation inspection palpation includi: Observation/inspection/palpation  (including skin assessment) -Observe for muscle atrophy or hypertrophy when comparing extremities, which may be indicative of other causes of the medial elbow pain(17) -Is there any edema or erythema present?(15) -Patients typically have tenderness to palpation over the medial epicondyle(3,5)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Measure ROM of upper extremities using goniometry.Assess cervical and shoulder ROM as part of upper quarter screen
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Compare the biceps, triceps, and brachioradialis reflexes of the affected extremity to the unaffected extremity to rule out nerve pathology(6)Does pain contribute to impaired function of involved upper extremity and affect ADLs?
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Complete a dermatome scan (may test ability to perceive light touch, deep pressure, temperature, etc.)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Special tests specific to diagnosis -Ask the patient to extend elbow and allow for wrist to be passively extended; is there pain with this activity?(5) -Ask the patient to extend elbow and provide resistance as the wrist is moved into flexion; is pain present during this test?(3,5) -With medial epicondylitis, resisted wrist flexion and forearm pronation typically are painful(3) -Special tests utilized to assist in ruling out cervical pathology include (assess appropriateness of implementing these(6) -compression test -distraction test -Valsalva test -swallowing test -thoracic outlet testing -Tinel test for ulnar nerve -Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure

contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Cryotherapy  contraindications(6) -Raynaud’s syndrome -Cryoglobulinemia  -Cold urticaria -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Impaired circulation -Over area of nerve regrowth
Cryotherapy  precautions(6) -Hypertension -Hypersensitivity to cold -Over an acute wound -Over superficial nerves

Thermotherapy  contraindications(6) -Decreased circulation -Decreased sensation -Acute/subacute traumatic and inflammatory conditions -Skin infections -Impaired cognition or language barrier -Malignancy -Liniments or heat rubs -Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema -Heat rubs

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions(6) -Do not place electrodes near: -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads -Osteomyelitis -Hemorrhage -Impaired sensation, mental status, communication -Cardiovascular disease -Malignancy -Dermatological conditions -Proximity of electromagnetic radiation -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen -In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck -History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women

Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use:(7) -Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker -Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy -Over the eyes or testes -In an area with infection or bleeding -If a tumor or malignancy is present in the area -In the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis -Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia -Over epiphyseal plates

Therapeutic ultrasound  precautions(7) -Sensory deficits -Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier) -Circulatory impairments -Plastic or metal implants -Peripheral vascular disease -Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment
Evidence is lacking or controversial regarding the effectiveness of electrophysical modalities (e.g., ultrasound, laser, TENS, extracorporeal shock wave therapy) in epicondylalgia(14)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Pain, edema, reduced strength, and reduced ROM with loss of function  Rule out  (2,13,15) Ulnar or medial collateral ligament sprain or tear Ulnar neuropathy Occult fracture Cervical radiculopathy Valgus extension overload syndrome Posteromedial elbow impingement Arthritis Shingles Osteochondritis dissecans Synovitis Myofascial pain complex Bone infection/tumors
prognosis: Treatment is less effective if provocative activity is not modified or eliminated. Patients are more likely to have successful treatment if pain is localized and they have no other upper extremity pain, can recall specific onset of pain, and are less symptomatic at rest than when performing provocative activities(4)
The condition is usually self-limiting  and 80% of patients recover within 1 to 3 years(15)
For patients who fail to improve with conservative treatment, surgery may be appropriate. After surgery, 80% of patients improve by at least 80%(4)

Prognosis is worse with the following conditions:(2) –When dominant hand is involved –Persistent symptoms > 3 months –Patient experiences high physical strain at work –Patient experiences severe pain at presentation and concomitant neck pain
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physician for possible corticosteroid injection, surgical intervention Occupational therapist (OT) for ADLs or self-care  deficits resulting from pain
other considerations: Local corticosteroid injection can reduce pain and inflammation(2,4,15)
Autologous whole blood injection or platelet-rich  plasma is an option for treating musculoskeletal injuries, including medial epicondylitis, but additional research into efficacy is needed(12)
treatment summary: Treatment in early or acute stage should focus on pain management with physical modalities (ultrasound, electrical stimulation, heat, ice, massage, phonophoresis, or referral for corticosteroid injection) followed by a gradual exercise program to improve strength and endurance of the wrist flexors(1,13)

Transverse friction massage and kneading in conjunction with ultrasound to the common flexor tendon at the medial epicondyle may be more effective than ultrasound alone in decreasing pain and improving function in patients with ME(8) –Based on an RCT in India –Twenty patients with ME were randomized to ultrasound vs. ultrasound plus massage therapy –The ultrasound and massage therapy were administered for 15 days –The ultrasound plus massage therapy group had a greater decrease in pain than the ultrasound group –The ultrasound plus massage therapy group was able to return to normal activities after 15 days whereas the ultrasound group was not

Modalities, including iontophoresis, ESWT, massage, TENS, phonophoresis, and ultrasound, may be effective in decreasing symptoms of medial epicondylitis, but the evidence supporting their use is limited(15)

Kinesiologytaping may improve pain but not wrist flexor strength in baseball pitchers with ME(9) –Based on a Taiwanese research study of 10 baseball players with ME and 10 age-, weight-,  and height-matched  athletes without ME –All participants received three types of taping: placebo, no taping, and kinesiology taping

. Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain and edema around medial epicondyleEliminate pain/edema Patient education _ Educate patient on the causes of ME and encourage patient to avoid aggravating activities for at least 6 weeks(3,10) _ _ Manual therapy _ Transverse friction massage to the flexor tendon(8) _ _ Physical agents and mechanical modalities _ Ice or ice massage as needed to decrease pain.(10) Do not place ice over ulnar nerve(10) _ _ _ Iontophoresis (see Treatment summary , above) _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Provide and adjust generic wrist cock-up splint to allow inflamed muscles/tendons to rest(5) _ _ A counterforce brace may also be trialed(15) _ _ Modify activity as indicated by symptoms; avoid provocative activities(15)Discontinue use of modalities, splints, and braces as appropriateProvide strategies for home that address the patient’s pain _ Instruct patient to ice area for 5–10 minutes 4–6 times a day and for 5–10 minutes following exercises(10)  Loss of elbow ROM Restore normal elbow ROMTherapeutic exercises _ Passive and active ROM exercises initiallyStretching, as indicated and tolerated, to tightened muscle groupsProvide strategies for home that address ROM/muscle tightness Loss of elbow/wrist strengthRestore normal upper extremity strengthTherapeutic exercises (5,10) _ Begin strengthening weakened musculature initially with isometrics. Gradually progress to resisted exercise (including eccentric exercise) as symptoms allow(3) _ _ It is important to note that the position of the upper extremity will impact the intensity of the activity _ _ Instruct the patient in exercises that will maintain/increase strength in muscle groups about the shoulder and scapulaThrower’s program can help athletes safely participate in throwing activities and prevent injury or reinjury(11)Provide recommendations for home centered on muscle strengthening as indicated Loss of function of involved upper extremity/loss of ability to participate in sportReturn to prior level of function/sportFunctional training _ Modification of throwing/swinging technique for provocative sport; modification of other provocative activities as they pertain to the individualProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedProvide activities/ instruction for home centered on return to function, as indicated .

maintenance or prevention: The following may reduce the risk of recurrence of ME(8,10) Regular, appropriate warm-up,  cool-down,  strengthening, and stretching activities Use of well-fitting  equipment Modification or elimination of provocative or exacerbating activities Limiting child pitchers to age-appropriate  types of pitches and number/frequency of pitches Throwing athletes should also strengthen the lower extremities and core muscles to improve kinetic chain and decrease stress on shoulder and elbow Use of appropriate techniques during sports
patient education: See “Medial Epicondylitis” from the Medscape website at http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/97217-overview#showall
See “Medial Epicondylitis” from American Society of Hand Therapists patient education resources at https://www.asht.org/ sites/default/files/docs/2018/Media%20Epicondylitis%202018.pdf

See “Therapeutic Exercise Program for Epicondylitis (Tennis Elbow/Golfer’s Elbow) from American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons (AAOS) at https://orthoinfo.aaos.org/globalassets/pdfs/a00790_therapeutic-exercise-program-for-epicondylitis_final.pdf Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
